title: Before 14 December 2021, will the World Trade Organization (WTO) officially agree to grant waivers for intellectual property protections for COVID-19 vaccine technology?
preds: 0% by 14 December. Maybe if the question asked about the vaccine IP waivers and then about the IP waivers on vaccine technologies, I would increase the probability, but I cannot see any agreement made in regards to the technology underpinning mRNA.
Sadly, 'omicron' is proof that not granting IP waivers was a stupidly mistaken decision of greedy idiots.
Thanks to @jleibowich who alerted me to the news that the WTO conference has been postponed. https://abcnews.go.com/amp/Travel/wireStory/official-wto-delays-key-meeting-amid-covid-variant-81411081

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/26/biden-calls-for-intellectual-property-waivers-covid-vaccines Since nobody in the US pays much attention to the Current Recumbent, his entreaties aren't likely to generate much action elsewhere--or at least not in the next few weeks.
The phrasing is noncommittal and the resistance would be substantive
well, even the Pope is pleading for this so , raising odds.
As with climate change words and actions of the US government do not match up.
The incentives to avoid further surges with all the accompanying lockdowns and deaths are very strong, despite the legal complexities.
Vaccine manufacturers are rather well prepared for the dispute now. The time of first shock - impact - is definetly over.
Vaccine manufacturers are raising prices for the EU, which is a sign they're not worried about losing their exclusivity.
It will never be even on the floor.
No change coming out of G7 meeting other than announcement of donation/provision of doses.  Lowering a bit.

Wow, this is an incredibly interesting and consequential question. Ultimately, I think momentum on this decision will be largely dictated by what the virus decides to do over the next several months. If the pandemic continues to rage in many parts of the world and new variants emerge (which seems more likely than not at the moment, though I hope I am wrong), I have to believe that momentum will shift sharply toward a WTO waiver by the end of the year in an effort to rein in the pandemic. Otherwise not.
If Covid vaccine is needed once a year it will
If this was to happen don't think it would be via WTO.

EDIT:
"EU aims to disrupt the negotiations with these “new” proposal, which is nothing more than CLs as we know. We have a good momentum now with the US, along with 100 countries backing it. India and South Africa have submitted a revised proposal [...]"
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/europe-unions-new-move-may-hit-india-south-africas-patent-waiver-plan/articleshow/83325809.cms

I'm persuaded by @colombus that, when there's strong disagreement and need for consensus, the status quo is most likely. It's also more likely that the vaccine companies themselves may release their IP than being forced to by a global consensus, and the former would be politically safer than the latter.

Many countries look to the United States when it comes to WTO policy. It is well known that Biden will be nicer to leaders in the public eye (compared to DJT) and while I suspect he will be tougher in private. If Biden supports it, I see the majority of countries fighting against the intellectual property waivers.  Although it wouldn't surprise me if some countries nationalize the IP and then release it without WTO intervening (looking at you, Germany!)
I think it is quite clear that the EU is not going to change its position - and as time goes on, the issue will become less pressing.

COVID remedies are already produced in many plants despite being designed in one.  There is no need to waive, since all facilities are already efficiently producing at capacity regardless of company.  Demand is just that high.  The only difference it would make is for vaccine designers to not get paid as much for their work.  Political will goes a long way.  But that far?
It looks like the EU is against it

The German government is against it, although Biontech, itself a German company, would temporarily waive the patent right. I think this will drag on because of that resistance until there are other solutions. Germany didn't let itself be talked into Nordstream either, whether you think it's good or bad.  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/may/06/us-germany-rift-covid-vaccine-patent-waivers

I assume many of the decisions made by the WTO would be heavily influenced by economists. The economics of the waivers seems weak: they reduce an incentive for R&D without much of a benefit to global health: https://www.economist.com/business/2021/05/08/america-wants-to-waive-patent-protection-for-vaccines As mentioned by others, the base rates on these is low. But, the base rates might not fit the 'global pandemic' box on this kinda proposal. Waivers are politically attractive (no-one loves big pharma, and the public might believe the waivers would help) so I can see a big push for heads of state to publicly endorse them
FT reports on Brussels pushing back to use other methods than waivers

Waivers for IP protections don't appear very uncommon (I searched for 'IP Waiver' on the WTO document portal and found several prior to 2020 in the first couple of batches). There will be enormous pressure to grant this waiver (if only to appear to be helping) as the rich world recovers and deaths in many poor countries accelerates. I think there's a much higher chance of this than people think.

The waiver would at best provide symbolic benefit since capital costs for the plant,  business process design,  distribution logistics, and manufacturing controls would have more to do with the ability of other developed and developing world facilities to execute large volume manufacturing than just the simple access to the IP. The IP holders would have to actively cooperate to execute on any of that, and at a minimum, they remain focused on their own delivery which disincents them from applying management bandwidth to technology transfer IP waiver would also imply liability waiver- a challenge for the holders to grant  IP waiver would on the other end of the decision scale create an ominous precedent and diminution of the comprehensible rules for other politically sensitive product sets such as agricultural technologies, medical instruments, and the overall set of pharma products. Participants might balk at such a precedent Practically getting the required timely majority vote at the WTO would be daunting

the consensus system of the WTO would need many players to agree to something that for certain countries goes against their fundamental national interests an exemption now could open the door for others later. Countries like Switzerland would very much want to avoid that

US supports which means rest of west won’t stand in way and rest of world doesn’t hold patents and companies can make their money out of production knowledge and experience instead of patents as the production yield is hard to get right as proven by the EU vaccine cactories production ratio.

The USA is declaring support for waiving Most Western liberal democracies are likely to follow. They are not likely to 'veto' the decision anymore. Most developed countries seem open to the idea of discussing Brazil (being the only developed nation against waiving) has waived IP for HIV/AIDS-related cases (https://www.hrw.org/news/2021/03/09/brazil-su pport-wider-vaccine-production-wt) 70% Yes 30% No with a chance of possibly being announced after December 14 (deadline is on early January) giving 69% yes, 31% no.
The vaccine is already worldwide medicine.
Large companies will resist the compromise of intellectual property
The way US government went so go’s WTO
The US have a collective memory of previously having stood up for morals higher than self-interest (WWII, Cold War). Hopefully Biden wants to pick that back up and this is not just a PR stunt.
Takes all 164 members to agree for waiver to be granted it would be the greatest feat of diplomacy
